 Plans for operating a vehicle if the driver is injured.
 

 Plans for moving a vehicle if it's disabled.
 

 Plans for reacting if someone is wounded. Or two people. Or three.
 

 The point is - we train for every contingency we can think of, and we do it until it's second-nature.
 

 The reason is simple - the difference between a crisis and a disaster is preparation.
 

 We can't control everything that happens on the battlefield, but we can control how prepared we are, and what we do next.
 

 If we're unprepared - that could be the difference between life or death.
 

 And at the heart of every mission is one goal - minimize the loss of life.
 

 When I left the military, I applied the same training to how I protect my family and our home.
 

 I realized that I needed some kind of "early warning system" - something that would tell me when my home was in danger if I wasn't around.
 

 So my wife and I installed an alarm system.
 

 But after a few months with an alarm, I started feeling uneasy about how I was protecting my family.
 

 I had done enough research to know that the average police response time to a break-in could be 20 minutes or more.
 

 So while I felt better knowing that the alarm would notify police for me, it didn't actually protect my family.
 

 Think about it - by the time the alarm is going off, the intruder is already inside, and A LOT can happen in 20 minutes.

 What if they get a shot off first?
 

 What if there's 5 of them? 10?
 

 What if they came in the exterior door to my bedroom?
 

 In that case, I'd be in a life-or-death fight before the alarm even went off.
 

 What if my weapon jammed?
 

 Even with all my training, I'd have just seconds to fix my weapon in pitch black, having just been jolted awake in the dead of night.
